Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Atlantic Decadal-to-Multidecadal Variability and Predictability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research under this award will examine the variability and predictability of Atlantic sea surface temperatures (SSTs), with a particular focus on the role of "weather noise" in producing decadal and multidecadal SST fluctuations. Weather noise refers to the variability of weather patterns which is independent of SSTs and occurs owing to the chaotic nature of air movements. Despite their short duration, weather systems produce air-sea thermodynamic fluxes which can be a significant source of low-frequency SST variability, through the reddening effect of the long thermal relaxation time of the ocean mixed layer. A key tool in the research, developed during the PIs' previous NSF grant on this topic, is a modified version of the NCAR Community Climate System Model (CCSM) referred to as the Interactive Ensemble CCSM (IE-CCSM). The IE-CCSM addresses the role of weather noise by dramatically reducing it, so that the weather noise mechanism can be seletively enabled or disabled. The procedure used in IE-CCSM is to integrate multiple copies of the atmospheric component model of the coupled climate model, and use the average of the surface fluxes from all copies to force the ocean component model. Each atmospheric component model will have different weather noise, thus the weather noise will be removed by averaging over all the copies. The ocean component model interacts only with the average of the atmospheric component models, and thus does not "see" the weather noise. Experiments conducted with the IE-CCSM will examine the importance of weather noise for four major patterns of Atlantic SST variability: a tripole SST pattern in the northern North Atlantic which is associated with the North Atlantic Oscillation, a monopole SST anomaly in the North Atlantic associated with Atlantic multidecadal variability, and which may be related to variability of the Atlantic meridional overturning circuation, and two patterns of tropical Atlantic variability, a zonal structure resembling the Pacific El Nino phenomenon, and a meridional structure characterized by changes in the cross-equatorial SST gradient. The research also include experiments to understand the impact of weather noise on the predictability of Atlantic SST variability.

The work has eduational broader impacts through its support for three graduate students, which will help to develop the next generation of scientists in this research area. In addition, the research may lead to insights into the variability and predictability of the climate system over long time periods, which would be of interest to policy and decision makers concerned with the impacts of climate variability and change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific Outcomes

The scientific and technical issues addressed by this project are of fundamental importance for the understanding of climate variability, for the detection and attribution of climate change, and for the practical problem of climate prediction. 

The causes of multidecadal variability of SST in the Atlantic were investigated. The SST variability was produced by long simulations using the NCAR CCSM3 CGCM. Some of the simulations used constant 1990 external forcing (solar, greenhouse, and volcanic), while others included estimated 1890-2000 external forcing. The multidecadal SST variability in both sets of simulations resembles the observed AMV (Atlantic Multidecadal Variability) pattern of a coherent single signed pattern over most of the North Atlantic. The diagnosis of causes was novel in that it used the Interactive Ensemble (IE) version of the CGCM, which filters out the ocean variability produced by the atmospheric weather noise, but preserves the full complexity of the CGCM physics and dynamics.

The fundamental issue of the role of atmosphere-ocean coupling in explaining the apparently different statistics of an atmospheric GCM forced by specified SST and the statistics of a coupled GCM producing the same SST was addressed in order to justify the experimental design. Understanding the role of coupling is of fundamental importance to the whole climate modeling enterprise. This project is the only one to have investigated this issue systematically to our knowledge.

The "null hypothesis" that the AMV in a CGCM simulation was forced by weather noise surface fluxes was tested by extracting the weather noise surface fluxes from the CGCM simulation and then deterministically applying that forcing to the IE. In the constant external forcing case, the results were consistent with a version of the null hypothesis, and it was concluded that the simulated AMV was produced primarily as a response to temporally random but spatially organized weather noise, primarily with the large scale spatial structure of the North Atlantic Oscillation. The weather noise forced response was further decomposed into the parts due to heat flux, wind stress, and fresh water flux, and it was found that the fresh water flux was not important. In the region of the strong currents of the separated Gulf Stream, the AMV was produced by the noise wind stress, while the noise heat flux produced a broader scale response over the eastern part of the basin. The oceanic gyre circulation variability associated with the AMV was forced by the noise wind stress, but the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC) varied primarily in response to the noise heat flux. In the simulations forced by the time evolving 20th century external forcing, both external forcing and weather noise forcing made important contributions to the AMV. The noise-forced AMOC led the noise-forced part of the AMV by about five years, indicating a possible role for the AMOC in the growth and demise of AMV events.

Broader Impacts

The project has contributed to conceptual development of the CESM software infrastructure. The research performed has led to applications beyond the immediate scientific questions addressed.  These include an important unanticipated application in ocean data assimilation at NCAR, and application of the interactive ensemble concept in convective parameterization. The project has produced three PhD recipients, including two women and one underrepresented minority.
